oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nanomaterials in food and agriculture: The big issue of small matter for organic food and farming
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Paull, John
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: "Organics" in general
Values, standards and certification
Food systems
Knowledge management
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Nanotechnology is the study of very small matter, of materials where one dimension is less than 100 nanometres. Surveys reveal that consumers are generally ignorant of nanotechnology, are concerned of its risks versus benefits, expect labelling of products incorporating nanotechnology, and a big issue for respondents is particularly the use of nanotechnology in food. Organic standards of Australia, Canada, Demeter-International and the UKâ€™s Soil Association exclude nanomaterials, however a general nanotechnology exclusion across the organics sector is lacking.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Paull, John (2011) Nanomaterials in food and agriculture: The big issue of small matter for organic food and farming. In: Neuhoff, Daniel; Halberg, Niels; Rasmussen, I.A.; Hermansen, J.E.; Ssekyewa, Charles and Sohn, Sang Mok (Eds.) Proceedings of the Third Scientific Conference of ISOFAR, ISOFAR, Bonn, 2, pp. 96-99.
